awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Developing the Geospatial Data Analytics Certificate Program at Fayetteville State University
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The Geospatial Data Analytics (GEODATA) Certificate at Fayetteville State University (FSU) will expose students to new career opportunities, since geospatial technologies have recently experienced robust job growth and is rapidly gaining momentum in the industry, with wide ranging applications. The traditional and online courses will serve a broad range of students, including underrepresented minorities and non-traditional students who attend FSU.

The GEODATA Certificate program will educate undergraduate students in computational and data-enabled science in the context of geospatial applications. The proposed project is based on educational research that suggests Computer Science curricula can benefit from creating pathways built from contexts, which are application and domain areas that cover core knowledge by providing explanations and motivation for students. The interdisciplinary computing classes of the program are thus expected to aid in recruitment and retention and provide benefits for students seeking new career opportunities in STEM. The GEODATA program will add to the growing body of knowledge on how to motivate students in the study of computing, how to prepare them for the modern-day job market, and how to develop their core knowledge and skills by using the geospatial context. Proposed activities consist of course development and redesign, setting up the geospatial-computing infrastructure and equipment, implementation of the certification program and development of fully online counterparts of existing program courses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Geospatial Data Analytics program, referred to as the GEODATA program later, was established at Fayetteville State University with funding from the National Science Foundation. The primary aim of the project was to create new courses and re-design some existing courses in Computer Science to teach core knowledge using the pathway and context of computer-based storage and analysis of geospatial data. Studies show that development of spatial analysis skills can enhance student abilities in computational thinking and that these skills can be developed. During the period of NSF funding the principal investigators of the GEODATA program have contributed scholarly articles to the growing body of knowledge on how to motivate students in the study of computing, how to prepare them for the modern-day job market, and how to develop their core knowledge and skills by using the geospatial context. Geospatial data is data any type ? image, passages of text, social media posts etc. which have a geospatial tag that makes it possible to find the locations where the data was created and modified. Geospatial data analytics is very useful in business operations and the functioning of the government. The interdisciplinary, computation-oriented classes of the program are providing the context in which computing students can apply their skills, and thus gain deeper knowledge of their discipline. Other non-computing students are learning additional skills to enhance abilities in their own disciplines. This program has opened up new career possibilities for all students, since geospatial technologies have experienced robust job growth in the recent years. The GEODATA program has educated and continues to educate undergraduate students in computational and data-enabled science in the context of geospatial applications. Existing or emerging businesses can be transformed by the knowledge and abilities of the student scholars of the program as they join the workforce. In particular, geospatial data analytics, which is a focus area of the program, is rapidly gaining momentum in the industry with wide ranging applications. The traditional and online offerings of courses from this program are benefiting underrepresented minorities along with non-traditional students who attend FSU, and this aligns well with the recommendations for HBCUs to modernize curricula and to make them available online. The time period of the NSF funded project overlapped with the devastating Covid pandemic which disproportionately affected minority communities. The GEODATA program was able to adapt to the significant challenges of these times by offering courses in online format and engaging students in research and extracurricular learning experiences in virtual mode. The efforts to recruit students into the program were negatively affected by university shutdowns and other emergency measures during the pandemic. The perseverance of the students, the investigators of the project, other department faculty and staff through these difficult times has successfully established the program and made it available for future students.


Last Modified: 07/23/2022
Modified by: Sambit Bhattacharya

Images (1 of )
  • Students in the Geospatial Data Analytics Program presenting at a conference. The research topic is detection of surface oxidation of outdoor objects like cellular towers, by performing analysis of data from geographic locations which have transportation structures.
    Sambit Bhattacharya
    Public Domain
    Sambit Bhattacharya
    Conference poster presentation by students
  • Students in the Geospatial Data Analytics Program presenting at a conference. The research topic is detection of surface deterioration of roads, bridges etc. due to mechanical forces, by performing analysis of data from geographic locations which have transportation structures.
    Sambit Bhattacharya
    Public Domain
    Sambit Bhattacharya
    Conference poster presentation by students
  • Students in the Geospatial Data Analytics Program complete their senior design project. The research topic is detection of small, hard to detect objects in geospatial locations. The application is geospatial surveillance. The students worked with researchers from the US Department of Defense.
    Sambit Bhattacharya
    Public Domain
    Sambit Bhattacharya
    Students complete their senior design project
  • The Geospatial Data Analytics program flyer which was created and distributed to recruit students to the program. It describes classes, professional and career outlook and states the stipend offered from NSF funding to program scholars.
    Sambit Bhattacharya
    Public Domain
    Sambit Bhattacharya
    Program flyer
  • The topic is ADADATA, a proprietary database of Masego Inc. ADADATA is a database on human geography. The speaker is the CEO of Masego Inc. and Geospatial Data Analytics students are in the audience.
    Sambit Bhattacharya
    Public Domain
    Sambit Bhattacharya
    Industry seminar
